page.title: 10S.W.GUILDFORD:PUBLIC HOUSES
page.content: The Public Houses in this area vary in some respects, though none are particularly memorable. The Bull's Head, The Three Pigeons, and The Royal Oak are all traditional, friendly and have atmosphere. But The Greyhound, The Star, The Spread Eagle, and The Jolly Farmer are disappointing for such an attractive old town as this. The Brittannia has the attraction of being on the river though little else. The pubs most attractive to young people are The Black Friars and The King's Head; the former is tastelessly decorated and fails to create a pleasant atmosphere whereas The King's Head has friendly service, a quite understated appeal and a garden which other Guildford pubs sadly lack. Generally, the pubs are more rowdy than cosy and more town-like than countrified. J.Roberts & J.Baldock
